But the wind is blowing the wrong way, and the tear gas drifts back toward the trucks. The scabs begin to cough. A couple of them jump over the tailgate of the first truck and run. That starts a panick rout. Other scabs tumble out of the trucks and run back down the road to escape the tear gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: staring at the action. Esperanza can't stand it any longe She hands the baby to Ramуn and is gone before he realize her intent.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: running diagonally down the slope toward the picket post. In the distance we see deputies still battling the women. The deputies seem to have lost their heads. They lash out viciously at any woman who confronts them, in a vain attempt to scatter the women and clear the road. CLOSER ANGLE: THE PICKET POST. Luz Morales is climbing Vance's back, clinging to his arm Another woman clutches at his gun hand, trying to prevent him from drawing his pistol. Esperanza comes running up. She stops for a second, slips off her right shoe. Vance knocks the other women down, pulls his revolver from his holster. Esperanza whacks him over the wrist with her sho knocking the weapon out of his hand. Luz digs into his ha with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAM
dialogues.text: helpless, speechless, holding the baby. Suddenly he runs out of scene. Luнs grabs Estella's hand, follows. ANOTHER PART OF THE HILL: THE LOWER SLOPE. Charley and Frank are watching the action. Ramуn comes running into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you standing there? Do something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But women are getting hurt! We've gotta take over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're doing all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins, looks at baby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, looks like you've got your hands full. Completely frustrated, Ramуn looks down at the tiny bundl in his arms. Then he looks off at: THE PICKET POST: LONG SHOT FROM RAMУN'S ANGLE. We can see Barton calling his men off. He jumps in the ca turns it around. Several deputies climb aboard as he driv off. The others retreat on foot, leaving the two abandone trucks. The women re-form their lines, and begin to sing "The Union Is Our Leader."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramуn paces the floor fretfully, puffing on a cigarette. The baby crib is in a corner, and Juanito is wailing. Estella tries to match her father's caged-lion stride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a growl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So'm I. Luнs enters from the front door. Ramуn glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's coming. Charley Vidal gave her a lift. The boy starts off, then turns back again, his eyes glowi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy! Did you see the way Mama whopped that deputy with her shoe? Knocked the gun right out ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thundering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you hanging around there, hear? We hear the sound of a chugging truck outside. Ramуn goes to the window, peers out. EXT., ROAD OUTSIDE QUINTERO COTTAGE. MEDIUM SHOT. The union pick-up, full of women, stops at the gate. Esperanza and Luz sit beside Charley in the cab. They get out. All the women are laughing and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Esperanza enters. She is dirty, bedraggled, and bone-tired -- but there is a new light in her eyes, and when she smiles she grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoping for the worst)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. She kisses him lightly on the cheek, kisses Estella and Luнs, crosses immediately to the crib, glances at Juanito and enters the kitchen. CAMERA PANS with her. Ramуn follo slowly, halts in the kitchen doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must've been some experience for you, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you got enough today to last a lifetime, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back tomorrow. She emerges from the kitchen with the baby's bottle, crosses to the crib. The infant's wailing ceases abruptly Ramуn comes over, scowling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might get hurt. (No response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, if you think I'm gonna play nursemaid from now on, you're crazy ... I've had these kids all day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had them since the day they were born. She exits to the kitchen. Ramуn trails after her. INT., KITCHEN. MEDIUM SHOT. Esperanza works swiftly, putting pots and pans on the stove, preparing supper, etc. Ramуn continues to scowl at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you. I don't stay home with these kids tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then, tomorrow, I take the kids with me to the picket line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are fewer women on the line than on the first day, but they march with the same assurance and discipline as before. A good half of them crochet as they march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so I came back the next day -- and every day for the next month ... CAMERA PANS past the picket line to the coffee shack, MOVES ON to pick up a group of small children playing nea the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kept Juanito in the coffee shack, and when the weather was good and there was peace on the line I brought his crib outside. Estella played with the little ones, and Luнs ... CAMERA SWISH PANS to a clump of juniper on the hillside i deep b.g. We can make out Luнs, crouching there with several cronies, apparently plotting something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Luнs was in school. CAMERA SWISH PANS to another part of the hill, closer to the picket post. Ramуn can be seen reclining on the slope with several cronies. The men appear moody and depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramуn came every day and sat on the hillside, just watching. The ladies -- well, they criticized Ramуn for not keeping the kids. BACK TO PICKET POST. FULL SHOT. In b.g. women are crocheting, chatting as they march. The baby's crib, sheathed in mosquito netting, lies on a tabl outside coffee shack in f.g. Esperanza is changing the baby's diaper. Mrs. Salazar and Teresa are talking to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trucks and sheriff's cars can be seen parked near the picket line. The scabs and deputies stand in the trucks, jeering at the marching women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a while the Sheriff's men left us alone. But then it started again. They cursed us, insulted us, called us foul names. It started again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as a moving truck loaded with scabs tries to force its wa through the living wall of women. The women try to push t truck back. They cling to it, and the scabs lean down and beat them off. The truck lurches forward, striking a woma and flinging her onto the road. Several other women have opened the hood of the truck. They rip out ignition wires The truck stalls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck is gone. Four deputies wearing gas masks are firing tear gas shells into the picket line. The women retreat, fan out in a great arc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used tear gas again. This time the wind was against us. ANOTHER ANGLE, SHOOTING TOWARD HILLSLOPE. Esperanza and Estella can be seen running up the slope aw from the gas. Esperanza carries the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When that happened we spread out, as we had planned, and I took the baby away from the danger, as we had planned. BACK To PICKET POST. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. Instead of tear gas enveloping the picket line, the picke line envelops the drifting gas, re-forms again downwind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they couldn't break our line. They couldn't break it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where a small army of scabs and deputies is gathered. The scabs stand sheepishly beside the trucks. The Sheriff, Barton, and several deputies are gazing off at the picket line. They are no longer amused. The superintendent's Cadillac enters scene, coming up the road. It rolls to a stop near the Sheriff's party. CLOSE GROUP SHOT: AT CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopelessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried everything but shootin' 'em down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't tried locking them up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want 'em all arrested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just the ring leaders. The fire-eaters. And the ones with big families ... (to Barton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barton -- where's that boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waves, shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you -- c'mere. Sebastian Prieto, the fingerman, leaves a group of deputi in b.g. and comes over. The Sheriff glances at him with contempt, then starts toward the picket line, Prieto and the deputies moving with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they approach the line. The women keep on marching. Esperanza is among them, carrying the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting at them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, girls -- I'm gonna give you a choice -- you can go home or you can go to jail. No ifs, ands or buts. Git off the picket line or git arrested. Silence. The women keep on marching. The Sheriff turns to Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Point 'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a furtive mumble)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one -- Teresa Vidal. She's the leader. Kimbrough walks over to the line, grabs Teresa's arm as s marches by. CLOSER ANGLE, FEATURING KIMBROUGH AND TERESA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're under arrest. Home or the hoosegow -- what's it gonna be? Several of the women stop marching. Mrs. Kalinsky picks u a stick. They approach Kimbrough menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep marching sisters. Let's show some discipline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Teresa, we ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll charge us with resisting arrest. Keep marching! She jerks loose from Kimbrough and walks alone toward the trucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Sebastian fingers other women the deputies walk off on by one to arrest them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mrs. Salazar ... the old one. And Chana Dнaz -- that one, in the blue dress. And Luz Morales, the little one, shaking her fist ... and Mrs. Kalinsky, the Anglo ... and Ruth Barnes, she's the organizer's wife ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the women are plucked off the line, one by one. They do n resist. We call see Esperanza still marching. She seems t clutch the baby more tightly to her. Estella tags along beside her mother. REVERSE ANGLE, SHOOTING TOWARD TRUCKS. The back of one truck is already filled with women, and t other is filling rapidly. TWO SHOT: SHERIFF AND SEBASTIAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And Lala Alvarez, the pretty one over there. And that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sly grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's Ramуn Quintero's wife. He don't like her being here at all. The Sheriff hesitates a moment, his eyes narrowed in thought, then gives Vance the nod. Vance approaches the line. MEDIUM SHOT: AT PICKET LINE. Vance plucks at Esperanza's sleeve. She stops for a secon frightened, wavering. The women remaining on the line cal out to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take the baby, Esperanza ... Don't worry about Juanito ... We'll keep Estella too ... Vance pulls at her arm again. Esperanza stiffens with a sudden fierceness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The baby stays with me. (She stoops down to Estella.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to Papa. You stay with Papa, hear? Head high, carrying the baby, Esperanza walks off toward the waiting trucks. The little girl watches her go, beref perplexed. EXT., HILLSIDE. CLOSE SHOT: RAMУN. He comes to his feet, tense with anxiety. EXT., PICKET LINE. LONG PANNING SHOT FROM HIS ANGLE. Suddenly Estella breaks away from the picket line and run after her mother. Esperanza is climbing into the back of the second truck, which is now full. Estella jumps onto t tailgate and a woman pulls her up. We hear motors startin The trucks pull off slowly. At the same instant we hear Teresa's clear voice, singing "Solidarity Forever." The other women join her. The chorus swells. CAMERA HOLDS on the receding trucks, and the singing fades. Now the CAMER PANS SLOWLY BACK to the picket line. There are only a handful of women remaining. But from somewhere we hear th song again. CAMERA PANS ON, HOLDS on a view of the wooded hillside. Suddenly we see twenty or more women coming dow the slope with Consuelo Ruiz in the lead. They are singin these reserves, coming to replenish the gaps in the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the DISSOLVE WE HEAR the rhythmic clank of tin cups against steel bars. Lights come up slowly to reveal two adjacent jail cells packed with women. All are standing, for there is no room to sit down. The women in f.g. bang the bars, and all of them chant rhythmically in Spanish:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queremos comida ... Queremos camas ... Queremos baсos ... Queremos comida ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as seen from the cell. The two deputies are leaning back in their chairs against a blank wall opposite the cells. The deafening chant is driving the turnkey to distraction He puts his hands to his ears. Suddenly he rises and come over, holding up his hands for quiet. Vance follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen! Please, girls! Be quiet! Listen! (The din subsides.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you ten times. We don't have no food. We don't have no beds. We don't have no baths. So please -- please -- shut up! Vance grins at Luz Morales, whose face can be seen behind the bars in close foreground. He reaches out, chucks her under the chin. Luz scratches at his hand, and he withdra it. The chant is resumed. INT., REAR OF CELL. CLOSE GROUP SHOT. The one cot in the cell is occupied by Estella and the infant Juanito. Juanito is crying. Esperanza hovers worriedly over him, trying to get him a take a nippled bottle, which he rejects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Teresa)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't drink this milk. It'll make him sick. He's on a formula. (In a panic of guilt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a fool! I shouldn't have kept him with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you worry. We'll get some action. She moves off to the front of the cell, calling for quiet FRONT OF CELL, FEATURING TERESA. The women stop their clamor for a moment. Teresa calls ou to Vance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby can't drink this store milk. We want his formula!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The formula, the formula ... The women begin banging away with their cups again taking up the chant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want the formula! We want the formula! Vance winces at the noise. INT., COURT HOUSE HALLWAY. MEDIUM SHOT, NIGHT. Ramуn can be seen coming slowly up the hall. Luнs trails behind him. Ramуn walks like a man in enemy territory. From off scene the sound of the women's chant carries ove "We want the formula ..." THE HALL. ANOTHER ANGLE. Ramуn is passing a door marked: OFFICE OF THE DISTRICT ATTORNEY. The door is slightly ajar. Ramуn stops, turns back, looks inside. INT., DISTRICT ATTORNEY'S OFFICE FROM RAMУN'S ANGLE. All that can be seen in Ramуn's cone of vision is a desk across the room. The D.A.'s feet are on the desk. He is i his shirt sleeves, but wearing his hat. Alexander sits on the corner of the desk. Hartwell and the sheriff wander i and out of scene, pacing the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can get the J.P. to swear out peace bonds. Or heist the bail high enough so you can keep 'em in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep 'em? What am I supposed to do -- feed 'em outa my own pocket? BACK TO HALLWAY. RAMУN AND LUIS. Ramуn's hand is half-raised to the doorknob. It falls to his side. He listens. D.A.'s VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want to know, Mr. Hartwell, is when you gonna settle this thing. You won't negotiate with 'em. What are you after, anyway? MEDIUM SHOT: HARTWELL FROM RAMУN'S ANGLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pacing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company has other mines. You've got to see the larger picture. Once these people get out of hand ... Without noticing Ramуn, but conscious of the need to keep what he is saying confidential, Hartwell has moved to the door and closed it, cutting off the rest of his sentence.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAM
dialogues.text: frustrated in his desire to hear more. Just then Vance rounds a corner in b.g. and enters scene, walking toward CAMERA. He stops short, seeing Ramуn. For a moment they stare at one another. Vance looks scared, despite the fac that he is armed and within his own bastille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you doin' here? Ain't you seen enough of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scarcely audible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come for my kids. They're in your jail. Vance warily brushes past Ramуn and opens the office door gesturing for the Sheriff. During the few moments the doo is open, we hear: D.A.'s VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've played every trump in your hand and they're not dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not every trump. D.A.'s VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as what? The Sheriff comes out, closing the door behind him, cutting off the inside conversation again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't shut them dames up. They keep yellin' about the formula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Formula for the baby or somethin'. (Indicates Ramуn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His kid. The Sheriff glances at Ramуn and stalks off down the hall Vance follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Sheriff and Vance enter. The women's clamor is as loud as ever. The Sheriff holds up his hands for quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here. I got you some milk for the baby. So what's all the belly-achin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no good, the milk... Queremos la formula ... The baby has a formula ... If Juanito gets sick you'll be responsible ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not running a drug store. You girls got nobody but yourselves to 1 blame and you can be home with your families in an hour. All you have to do is sign a pledge that you won't go back to the picket line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English and Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sign nothin' for the stinker. No, no deals, no deals ... Make him get the formula. They start banging on the bars again. The sheriff turns angrily to Vance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd that fellow go? Vance takes a few steps, shouts around a corner, beckonin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pancho, c'mere! Ramуn enters scene, walking slowly into f.g. Luнs tags along behind. The women fall silent abruptly. It is very still. CLOSE GROUP SHOT: AT CELL DOOR. The Sheriff motions to the turnkey to unlock one of the cells. He obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright. Where's the baby? And the little girl? Esperanza brings the baby from the rear of the cell. Estella squeezes past the tightly packed women, joins her mother. Ramуn and Esperanza gaze at one another with deep poignancy, unsmiling. He holds out his hands. She gives the baby to him. Estella looks up at her mother. Esperanz nods, gives her a little push. Estella walks outside. Luн takes her hand. The father and his children walk off slow out of scene. The women watch them go. The turnkey locks the cell again. Suddenly they start banging on the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queremos comida ... Queremos camas ... Queremos baсos ... Queremos comida ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot matches the earlier scene of Luz and Esperanza - but now Ramуn and Antonio are hanging out the wash. Estella and the little Morales boy are there. Ramуn sees them playing in the baskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you kids get out of those baskets! There are two large wicker baskets beside the fence: one contains Juanito, the other a mountain of damp clothes. A he works, Antonio calls from across the fence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How goes it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never ends. He snaps out a damp undershirt, hangs it up. Suddenly he explodes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hours! Just to heat enough water to wash this stuff! (A pause. He goes on working.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you something. If this strike is ever settled -- which I doubt -- I don't go back to work unless the company installs hot running water for us. (Another pause.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should've been a union demand from the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We hear the baby wail. Ramуn walks over to the basket, pu the nipple of the bottle back in Juanito's mouth. Then he resumes his chores. Antonio muses as he works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like Charley Vidal says -- there's two kinds of slavery, wage slavery and domestic slavery. The Woman Question, he calls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Question, question -- the problem, what to do about 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? What does he want to do about 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says give 'em equality. Equality in jobs, equality in the home. Also sex equality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean -- sex equality?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know ... (Leers, shifts into Spanish.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's good for the goose is good for the gander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with a clothespin in his mouth, mulling over this concept His imagination runs away with him. He scowls thoughtfull

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's some organizer, that Charley. He can organize a wife right out of your home. Ramуn bites viciously on a clothespin and hangs up a pair of diapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two large tubs on the cluttered drainboard -- one of soapy water, one of rinse water. Ramуn is washing the dishes. Luнs is drying them. Ramуn is sweaty and sullen. Luнs is bored and impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, can't I leave now? There's a meeting of the Junior Shop Stewards ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Junior Shop Stewards. There's lots of ways we can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I have enough troubles without them shipping you off to reform school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Papa -- you need all the help you can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to help around the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've got me doing everything. Mama never used to make me dry the ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have helped her without being asked. At that moment we hear the raucous braying of an automobi horn from outside. Luнs dashes into the parlor. Ramуn sta there scrubbing a greasy dish. Now we hear gay laughter, and then, in Spanish:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buenas noches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasta maсana, Charley. INT., PARLOR. FULL SHOT: SHOOTING TOWARD FRONT DOOR. Ramуn enters scene f.g., stops. The front door bursts ope Esperanza enters. She embraces Luнs. He grins, responding with a shy, awkward hug. Esperanza looks at Ramуn. Her fa is aglow. She looks younger and heartier than we have eve seen her. She comes quickly into close foreground, embracing Ramуn. He puts his arms around her -- but stiffly, withholding himself. She looks up at him lovingl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. But it's nice to be home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four nights. How did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We raised such a fuss they finally brought cots in. She laughs; her hand goes to her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I nearly lost my voice, yelling so much. (Suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Estellita? And the baby? She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're asleep. INT., BEDROOM. MEDIUM SHOT. The bedroom is dark. Esperanza and Ramуn are only moving shadows. Dimly we see her hovering over the crib. Ramуn whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have to sign a pledge? Not to go back to the line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no ... we wouldn't do it. From off scene we hear a knock at the front door. Esperan crosses the dark room to answer it, Ramуn following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you go back they'll lock you up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no ... the Sheriff had enough of us. We drove him crazy. She goes out. INT., PARLOR. FULL SHOT. Esperanza opens the front door, admitting three women: Teresa, Ruth and Consuelo. They enter beaming, excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all set. Consuelo's squad can take they day off tomorrow. We're taking over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ushering them in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Come in, we'll work it out. Sit down, sit down. The three women sit down on the couch. Esperanza crosses the dining table to get a chair for herself. Ramуn is standing there. TWO SHOT: RAMУN AND ESPERANZA. He is the stern patriarch now. As she reaches for the cha he says, sotto voce:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to have a talk, you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but later. I've got a meeting now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suppressed outrage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. To plan for the picket line tomorrow. She walks off with her chair. CAMERA HOLDS on Ramуn. He i fuming. We hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now -- let's see ... who's available?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chana's husband is out of town -- on that delegation to see the governor. And Anita Gonzales' husband, too ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And six or seven others -- Lala's husband and Mariana's ... Ramуn looks like he's about to explode. INT., PARLOR. FULL SHOT. As Ramуn strides toward the front door, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's a whole bunch of men going on a fuel hunting expedition -- thirty or forty of them -- so their wives are out too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can ask them to keep our kids, so the rest of us can ... Ramуn exits, slamming the door loudly behind him. The wom react with a what's-eating-him look. Teresa turns sympathetically to Esperanza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do about him, Esperanza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time he was house broken. Maybe if a delegation of us talked to him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no ... I have to work it out with him myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven miners are seated on stools at the bar, drinking be These are the disconsolate ones -- the defeated and the perplexed, the traditionalist hold-outs and the unwilling babysitters. An atmosphere of gloom pervades the place. Their backs are to CAMERA, but seated from left to right they are: Jenkins, Antonio, two unidentified miners (whom we have seen around the picket line), Cente Cavazos, Josй Sanchez and Ramуn. The bartender, an Anglo, is a beefy, easy-going fellow with a friendly manner. He sets fresh beers before a couple of miners, but no money changes han We see the bartender mark something on a tab at the register. CAMERA MOVES ON to the next miner, an Anglo, leaning moodily on his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a friend, he's got a friend in the Bureau of Mines. Know what he says? They ain't never gonna open up that mine again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as CAMERA MOVES past him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says the ore's played out. So help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be. CAMERA HOLDS on Ramуn. There's a whiskey glass and a bott of beer before him. Ramуn is in a sodden blue funk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bull. Lotta bull. That's a rich mine. I know. He drinks off his whiskey, chases it down with beer, then stares moodily at the empty glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what's the difference? They'll never settle with us. Never. Suddenly we hear an excited shout:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! What d'ya know! FULL SHOT: MINERS AT BAR. Antonio holds up a magazine, stabbing a picture with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him! It's him! El Presidente! The President of the Company. All the miners except Ramуn get off their stools and come over, looking at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "MAN OF DISTINCTION. J. Hamilton Miller, financier, Business executive, Board Chairman of Continental Factors, and president of Delaware Zinc Incorporated. An enthusiastic sportsman and expert marksman, Mr. Miller manages to find time every year for an African safari. He leaves this month for Kenya, where he hopes to bag his thirteenth lion!" There is a long silence. The men stare at the portrait -- with hatred, with despair. Antonio rips the page out of t magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna frame this. (Turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ramуn -- look. Ramуn just grunts with disgust. He sips his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to look at the larger picture. A pall falls over the group again. The miners return to their bar stools. CLOSE MOVING SHOT (AS BEFORE).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring into space)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that? The guy is a lion hunter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you expect him to hunt -- rabbits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, oh man, I'd sure like to get me some venison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't tasted meat in four weeks. (Suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it, Ramуn? Let's take off for a couple of days, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ask me? Am I runnin' this strike? If you want permission to go over the hill, go ask the Ladies Auxiliary. He drains his beer, rises and stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dimly lit by one small lamp. Esperanza appears to be asle Ramуn enters, crosses to the bed and sits down a heavily. He begins to remove his shoes. CAMERA MOVES IN. Esperanza eyes come open, in the way of one who has been wide awake Without moving she says in quiet reproach:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I waited up till midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That meeting only lasted ten minutes. (A pause. Then quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first night I'm home, and you run to the beer parlor. What is it? Can't you bear the sight of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fierce whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be still ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you wanted to talk. Tell me. He rises suddenly and goes out. Esperanza slips out of be flings on a dressing gown. INT., KITCHEN. MEDIUM SHOT, NIGHT. Ramуn has a cup and is pouring coffee from the pot on the stove. Esperanza enters scene, stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't go on this way. I just can't go on living with you. Not this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We can't can't go on this way. We can't go back to the old way either. Ramуn sips his coffee, glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old way? What's your "new way"? What's it mean? Your "right" to neglect your kids? He goes abruptly to the parlor. Esperanza stands there a moment, then slowly follows him. INT., PARLOR. FULL SHOT. Ramуn goes to a closet, gets a rifle and a box of shells off the shelf. He sits down on the edge of a chair and begins to clean the rifle with an oily rag. Esperanza enters scene, watching him. There is a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramуn -- you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I'm not needed here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are needed. Especially now -- with most of the other men away. You're captain of the stand-by squad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, the standby squad. Stand-by for the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose funeral? We're doing all right. There hasn't been a scab near the picket line for three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know why? Because the company knows they can starve us out -- even if it takes another two, three months. What's it to them if the mine's shut down a little longer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot to them. They'd do anything to open that mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah! They've got other mines. You don't see the larger picture. (A pause.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got millions. Millions. They can outlast us, and they know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you're ready to give up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about giving up? I'll never go back to the company on my knees. Never. He pulls back the bolt of the rifle, inserts a cartridge, tests the bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go down fighting, is that it? (He shrugs.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go down fighting. I want to win. No response. She walks over to him, CAMERA FOLLOWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramуn were not getting weaker. We're stronger than ever before. (He snorts with disgust.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're getting weaker. They thought they could break our picket line. And they failed. And now they can't win unless they pull off something big, and pull it off fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But I can feel it coming. It's like ... like a lull before the storm. Charley Vidal says ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley Vidal says! (He rises, flinging rifle aside.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't throw Charley Vidal up to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley's my friend. I need friends. (She looks at him strangely.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you afraid to have me as your friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't. Have you learned nothing from this strike? Why are you afraid to have me at your side? Do you still think you can have dignity only if I have none?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk of dignity? After what you've been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I talk of dignity. The Anglo bosses look down on you, and you hate them for it. "Stay in your place, you dirty Mexican" -- that's what they tell you. But why must you say to me, "Stay in your place." Do you feel better having someone lower than you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you're talking crazy. But Esperanza moves right up to him, speaking now with great passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose neck shall I stand on, to make me feel superior? And what will I get out of it? I don't want anything lower than I am. I'm low enough already. I want to rise. And push everything up with me as I go ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be still?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you can't understand this you're a fool -- because you can't win this strike without me! You can't win anything without me! He seizes her shoulder with one hand, half raises the oth to slap her. Esperanza's body goes rigid. She stares straight at him, defiant and unflinching. Ramуn drops his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be the old way. Never try it on me again -- never. She crosses to the doorway, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to bed now. Sleep where you please -- but not with me. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dispirited and shivering, the women march, hunched agains the wind. Near the coffee shack is an oil drum in which a wood fire is burning. Teresa, the picket captain, walks toward Esperanza. Teresa closely watches Esperanza's dejected face. TWO SHOT: AT OIL DRUM. The two women warm their hands over the fire. Theresa mus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they had a little taste of what its like to be a woman ... and they run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Ramуn it's ... pride. I spoke out of the bitterness in me. And he was hurt. Esperanza stares at the fire. Teresa looks at her with de sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything worth learning is a hurt. These changes come with pain ... for other husbands too ... not just Ramуn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vista of wild and lonely beauty. A cold wind rustles th junipers and pine of a steep boulder-strewn arroyo. The deer hunters can be seen walking up a narrow trail in single file. They are bunched together, save for Ramуn, w lags behind. MEDIUM PANNING. SHOT, FEATURING RAMУN. He walks slowly up the trail into f.g., brooding. As he walks he hears Esperanza's voice of the preceding night, hauntingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you're ready to give up? (Pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go down fighting. I want to win. (Pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you learned nothing from this strike? (Pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can feel it coming. It's like a lull before the storm. (Pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now they can't win unless they pull off something big and pull it off fast. A shot is heard ringing through the arroyo. It pulls Ramу up short. He calls to the other men, suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers, we've got to go back! EXT., PICKET POST: WIDE ANGLE AT DRUM, INCLUDING TRUCK. Charley is at the wheel, Sal besides him. The truck stops near the oil drum. Charley leans out, calls urgently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esperanza! Where's Ramуn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramуn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he go hunting with the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Esperanza nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? Where can we find him? Do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. During this exchange several women have left the picket line and come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deer hunters! Deserters, that's what they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong? (Insistently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charley, tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Company's got an eviction order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS: Large close shot of young woman crying: "EVICTION! EVICTION!" Large close shot young boy crying "EVICTION! EVICTION! EVICTION!" Woman at clothesline hearing the call and leaving. Woman at kitchen door calling out "Where?" and leaving. Truck on road stops. Ma runs in, calls, "EVICTION! At the Quintero place." Car on road is stopped by several women; they pile in, the car pulls away. Shots of people walking, by twos and by group finally passing the car in which are seated Alexander and Hartwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a perturbed Hartwell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Quintero's gone hunting with the others. Evict him first; the rest will be easy. Let their neighbors watch. Scare some sense into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff's convoy is drawn up outside a row of company houses. We can see deputies milling about in the front ya of one of the cottages, and a cluster of women watching them from outside the fence. EXT., COTTAGE: CLOSER ANGLE. It is the Quintero place. The Sheriff stands in the front yard, directing operations. His deputies are lugging furniture out of the house. They dump it in the yard or a the side of the road. Several of them emerge from the fro door with the Quinteros' bed. Esperanza, Luz and a dozen other women silently watch the eviction from outside the fence. Mrs. Salazar is there with a bevy of kids (includi Juanito whom she holds in her arms). The only man present is the parish priest. EXT., MAIN ROAD, ZINC TOWN. LONG PANNING SHOT. We pick up Jenkins' car loaded with the stand-by squad roaring toward the housing area. The car passes the store the church, the school. As the car comes into f.g., and moves on out of scene, CAMERA HOLDS on the school playground. In the distance we see Luнs beckoning to a number of his companions. The boys set off at a run up th road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring Esperanza and Luz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we do something? No answer from Esperanza. She moves toward the front gate Other women follow her. CAMERA PANS with them. Just then the deputy Kimbrough comes through the gate carrying a la and a vase. He dumps them onto the road. The vase breaks. He shoves Esperanza roughly away from the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, girls -- get back, get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Jenkins' car swerves around the tail of the convoy, comes on up the road, stops near the cottage. Ramуn and t others pile out. They join the throng of women. Ramуn carries his rifle purposefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching the deputies as Ramуn comes to Esperanza's side. She sees him. Her face lights up. Ramуn's eyes meet hers for a moment. He is unsmiling. Then he looks away at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dumping the precious accumulations of a lifetime onto the road: the shrine, a kewpie doll, a faded photograph. CLOSE SHOT: PORTRAIT OF JUБREZ. It falls in the dust. The frame breaks.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO WATCHERS, FEATURING RAM
dialogues.text: his face working in hatred and anger. Esperanza is beside him now. He brings the barrel of his rifle up as if to level it. She glances at him in terror. Suddenly Ramуn go slack; the shadow of defeat crosses his face. With an abr movement he thrusts the rifle on Mrs. Salazar -- who take it, blinking with surprise. EXT., COTTAGE. FULL SHOT FROM THEIR ANGLE. Four deputies are emerging from the front door burdened with the ancient iron stove. CAMERA PANS away from them, holds on the fence separating the Quintero and Morales yards. Now we see Luнs and his cronies pop up from behind the fence. Each boy holds a grass-tailed clod. They let fly. CAMERA SWISH PANS BACK to the porch -- and we see two of the clods hit their target, spattering the deputie with dirt. One deputy drops his corner of the stove, and crashes down the steps. Several other deputies take off after the boys, leaving the gate unguarded. The sheriff yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind them brats! Come on -- get the work done. REVERSE ANGLE, FEATURING TENANTS. Other women, children and old men are arriving on the sce There are now over twenty women watching the eviction but there is no excitement, no talk. CLOSER ANGLE, FEATURING RAMУN AD ESPERANZA. Ramуn is calmer now, but alert, planning, thinking. He looks around at their gathering forces -- not yet impressive, but growing every moment. He almost smiles wi slow realization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what we've been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious, puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This means they've given up trying to break the picket line. (A pause.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we can all fight together -- all of us. Suddenly he draws Esperanza close, whispers something in her ear. She nods, turns swiftly to several other women, huddles with them a moment. CAMERA PANS with the women as they enter the yard, swooping down to pick up household belongings on their wa EXT., FRONT YARD. FULL SHOT. Other women, seeing what Esperanza and her sisters are up to, swiftly join them in the yard, begin to pick up furniture and carry it back into the house by way of the rear door. Deputies emerging from the house, loaded down with furniture and bric-a-brac, find themselves passing women loaded with objects they have just deposited in the yard. One of the deputies stops in close f.g., staring at the women in slack-jawed bafflement. Ramуn glances at Mrs Salazar. He winks. Mrs. Salazar smiles. It is the first time we have seen her smile. BACK TO YARD, FEATURING SHERIFF. His deputies are hopelessly dispersed. Half of them are chasing the boys, while the furniture-moving contingent i out-numbered by women crowding into the yard. The Sheriff wheels right and left in helpless exasperation. He spots Ramуn near the front fence, strides over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now see here, Quintero! These women are obstructin' justice. You make 'em behave, savvy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do nothing, sheriff. You know how it is -- they won't listen to a man any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blustering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to lock 'em up again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want 'em in your lock-up again? The Sheriff stalks off, fuming. EXT., ROAD AND YARD. FULL SHOT. More women keep arriving all the time. Several small fry, imitating their mothers, run into the yard, pick up lamps pots, pans, etc., and return them to the house. A SIDE ROAD. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. Two cars pull up and stop near the convoy. Consuelo Ruiz six other women get out, approach the cottage. THE YARD. FULL SHOT. From off scene we hear the blast of an automobile horn, while from the middle of the yard the sheriff bellows at his men:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Form a cordon! Keep 'em away from the house! Form a cordon! EXT., ROAD. MEDIUM LONG SHOT: PAST CONVOY. Two other cars pull up at the tail of the convoy. Frank Barnes and a half dozen miners get out, hurry toward the Quintero cottage. BACK TO YARD. FULL SHOT. By now the sheriff's men have reassembled and are forming cordon, from the porch steps to the front gate, permittin no one else to enter the yard. Four deputies pick up the Quinteros' bed and begin to carry it toward the truck. Wh they reach the gate they find it blocked by the six new miners and four of Ramуn's stand-by squad. The deputies stop, ease their burden to the ground. Just then we hear klaxon from o.s. Everyone turns to see: ANOTHER CONVOY. LONG PANNING SHOT. The union truck is in the lead. Charley Vidal is at the wheel, and the back of the truck is loaded with a dozen miners. Following it are a half-dozen miners' cars. The union convoy rolls past the parked sheriff's convoy, draw to a stop in f.g. The miners tumble out, move in a body toward the gate of the Quintero cottage. They are all big men, and their faces are grim and determined. We count 15 20, 25, 30 of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking at their approaching brothers. Alfredo nudges Gonzales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! The guys from the open pit ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the guys from the mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramуn, Esperanza and other women and children re-emerge from the house, stop on the porch in a compact mass. Faci them outside the gate are forty miners. The deputies are between. They stir nervously, glancing from side to side. No one says anything. A heavy stillness falls over the ya Now we see other women and children closing in at the sid fence: then Luнs and a half-dozen other boys appear at th opposite fence. The Sheriff is in dead center of this sho Without realizing it he makes a full turn of 360, looking at his adversaries. HIS ANGLE. SLOW PANNING SHOT. The Sheriff's forces are completely surrounded by over a hundred men, women and children. Appearing on the surrounding hills, on every side, are other miners, other women, other kids -- massed, impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turning, staring at the massed power against him. With an abrupt, frustrated gesture the Sheriff waves to his men to follow and walks out the gate. The miners break ranks to let him pass. When the last deputy has lef the yard the men close ranks and face the convoy. Still there is no voice, no sound save the starting motors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as seen from the porch, SHOOTING PAST the miners outside the gate. The convoy lurches into motion. The men watch i till the last car has passed. Then they turn to face the women, who enter scene f.g., moving down the steps, meeti the men in the yard. Suddenly someone laughs and then the is a release in laughter running through the crowd, and w hear half-whispered, awed comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English and Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stopped them ... It took all we had, but we stopped them ... When we heard about it at the mill, we just walked off ... Did you see their faces? .. . THE RECEDING CONVOY. LONG PANNING SHOT. The convoy approaches a crossroad a quarter of a mile downhill from the Quintero house. We see a Cadillac parke there at the corner. The lead car of the convoy stops and the sheriff gets out. He walks over to the Cadillac. CLOSE SHOT: AT CADILLAC. Alexander and Hartwell are sitting there. The sheriff starts to speak, then closes his mouth again. He indicate his empty trucks with a helpless gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any more ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively, passing the buck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't make policy. He looks at Hartwell. Hartwell puffs on a cigarette. Afte a long pause he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to New York. Maybe we better settle this thing. (Another puff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the present. BACK TO QUINTERO YARD. FULL SHOT. Part of the milling throng has already dispersed; those w remain are carrying the last of the Quinteros' possession back into the house. We see Luнs jump the fence and run toward his mother in f.g. She gives him a fierce hug. MEDIUM SHOTS AT FRONT GATE. Ramуn approaches Mrs. Salazar. He takes the baby from her arms. Estella enters the gate, dragging the portrait of Juбrez. Solemnly she lifts up the portrait. Ramуn takes it. He walks back toward the porch, Estella at his side. THE YARD, SWOOPING FROM THE PORCH. Esperanza and Luнs stand on the porch steps in f.g. Reaching them, Ramуn turns, looks back at his friends, some of whom are still in the yard. They seem to be waiting for him to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did not know then that we had won the strike. But our hearts were full. And when Ramуn said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks ... sisters... and brothers. The people smile softly. A few of them lift their hands i a wave of acknowledgment. They begin to leave. CLOSE UP SHOT: THE QUINTERO FAMILY ON PORCH. Ramуn holds the baby in the crook of his arm. He hands th portrait of Juбrez to Luнs. The boy gazes at it with respect, wipes the dust off it, and readjusts the torn frame. Ramуn heaves a long sigh. Unsmiling, he looks off the receding convoy. Esperanza watches him. There is a pause. Still not looking at her, Ramуn says haltingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esperanza ... thank you ... for your dignity. Esperanza's eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right. Together we can push everything up with us as we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I knew we had won something they could never take away -- something I could leave to our children -- and they, the salt of the earth, would inherit it. Esperanza places her hand in Ramуn's. With the children t walk into the house.
